comments.body: this hurts my head. I guess really what's going on here is you're using our layout needed signal to know when the size changes, since you only need to call _child._layout when the size changes. That seems reasonable.
Yeah, more specifically, I need to know when our size/constraints are up-to-date.  This is the first moment when they're ready to be sent to the child.
this should probably throw an exception, no?
Why?  Everything will work fine.  You'll just never see the child load.

Why print anything to the console then?

I think Flutter apps should, in correct operation, be completely silent on the console. Thus if we're printing something to the console, that means it's not correct operation. If it's not correct operation, it seems like we should signal a failure, which usually we do by an exception.

That makes a certain amount of sense.  This code is inside an assert(), which means it only executes in checked mode.  It's also inside a function that executes at most once per run of the app.  I guess when I wrote it, I was thinking it was a debugging aid, similar to dumpRenderTree.

Maybe the right thing to do is to show this message through the UI rather than through the console.  For example, in checked mode outside Mojo shell, we could replace the contents of the ChildView widget with this message.
